title: Ticket #328: DAGMan lazily evaluates and opens node job log files
description: This is already in progress, but I figured I should make a ticket for it.
remarks:
Basically, the idea is that we would deal with the log files as lazily as possible (at node submit time, rather than at DAGMan startup time).

The big change is that the multi-log-file code would have to be able to have a dynamic, rather than static, list of log files to monitor.

* Basic changes:

- Current log-file-related code to parse a DAG goes away (which means that condor_submit_dag will not check for log file specifications; that will only happen in DAGMan itself).

- We only monitor log files associated with active jobs in the DAG, rather than monitoring all relevant log files.

- Have a command-line flag for whether to check for valid log file specifications when parsing the DAG (defaults to yes).

* More details:

Have an object for each log file; all LogFile objects go into a hash table indexed by canonicaled file name; there is a side list with pointers only to the active file objects (for better performance).

struct LogFile { int refCount; int fd; long lastOffset; // maybe last timestamp of file // maybe other stuff }

* Interface to multi-log-file code:

MonitorLogFile(const char *logfile, bool recovery); - Make pathname canonical - Look for LogFile object in "main" list - If not found, create new LogFile object (includes file truncation if not in recovery mode) - If reference count is 0: - Open file - If file was previously used, seek to the proper location - Add to active list - Increment reference count

UnmonitorLogFile(const char *logfile, bool recovery); - Make pathname canonical - Find LogFile object in "main" list - Decrement reference count - If reference count is now 0: - Get and save current location in file - Close file - Remove from active list

ULogEventOutcome readEvent(ULogEvent * & event); - Go through all of the active log file objects and find the next unread event.

DAGMan calls MonitorLogFile() just before submitting a job; calls UnmonitorLogFile() just after dealing with the TERMINATED event for a job. At submit time, DAGMan will also save the log file name in the Job object, in case the submit file gets modified during the job's lifetime. When we're finished with the job, we can free the log file name string to save memory.

We need to save the list of inactive files in case one job uses a log file, then the log file becomes inactive, and later on another job uses it and it becomes active again -- we have to know to seek past the events we already saw when we re-open the file.

* Recovery mode:

In recovery mode, we'd have to register the log file for a job when it gets put into the ready queue. Hmm -- maybe we should just do it that way all the time to avoid having different cases in the code for "normal" mode and recovery mode. It would be less efficient, but simpler. Something to think about, anyhow.

* Rescue DAGs:

I don't think we'd have to do anything special when executing a rescue DAG.

* Advantages:

- Allows the possibility of lazy splice evaluation.

- Reduces the number of file descriptors used by DAGMan.

- Eliminates current duplicate DAG parsing code in the log file implementation.

- Allows more flexible "on-the-fly" generation of submit files; but overwriting a submit file that was used earlier in the DAG can cause problems and shouldn't be done (this is also true with the current log file setup).

* Possible future developments:

Phase 2: limit fd use by not keeping open fds to all active log files (fds would be opened and closed each time we get an event).

Phase 3: allow macros in log file names (but not $(JOB))

Phase 4: make node IDs unique across all DAGMan instances, so we don't need to truncate log files.

* Suggestions from Miron, 2008-10-28:

If a node job submit file doesn't specify a log file, DAGMan should specify a standard log file on the condor_submit command line. DAGMan could also delete that file at the end of the run (if successful), since the user presumably doesn't care about it. (Kent -- maybe there should be a config macro to turn off deleting the log file.)

Do something like "SUBDAG INLINE" instead of "SPLICE".

* Notes during implementation:

The ReadMultipleUserLogs destructor should print a warning if there are any "active" log files.

Hmm -- should the log code touch a non-existant log file when it's registered, so that we can open the file right away?
